# _Raiders of the Lost Ark_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the film. For other uses, see [Raiders of the Lost Ark
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark_\(disambiguation\) "Raiders of
the Lost Ark \(disambiguation\)").

_**Raiders of the Lost Ark**_ (also known as _**Indiana Jones and the Raiders
of the Lost Ark**_) is a 1981 American [action](/wiki/Action_film "Action
film") [adventure film](/wiki/Adventure_film "Adventure film") directed by
[Steven Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg"), with a
screenplay written by [Lawrence Kasdan](/wiki/Lawrence_Kasdan "Lawrence
Kasdan"), from a story by [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas")
and [Philip Kaufman](/wiki/Philip_Kaufman "Philip Kaufman"). It was produced
by [Frank Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(film_producer\) "Frank Marshall
\(film producer\)") for [Lucasfilm Ltd.](/wiki/Lucasfilm "Lucasfilm"), with
Lucas and [Howard Kazanjian](/wiki/Howard_Kazanjian "Howard Kazanjian") as
executive producers. Starring [Harrison Ford](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison
Ford"), it was the first installment in the [_Indiana Jones_ film
franchise](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_\(franchise\) "Indiana Jones \(franchise\)") to
be released, though it is the second in internal chronological order. It pits
[Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones") (Ford) against a group of
[Nazis](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") who are searching for the [Ark of the
Covenant](/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant "Ark of the Covenant"), which [Adolf
Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") believes will make his army
invincible. The film co-stars [Karen Allen](/wiki/Karen_Allen "Karen Allen")
as Indiana's former lover, [Marion Ravenwood](/wiki/Marion_Ravenwood "Marion
Ravenwood"); [Paul Freeman](/wiki/Paul_Freeman_\(actor\) "Paul Freeman
\(actor\)") as Indiana's rival, French [archaeologist](/wiki/Archaeologist
"Archaeologist") [René
Belloq](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Ren.C3.A9_Belloq
"List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"); [John Rhys-
Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies "John Rhys-Davies") as Indiana's sidekick,
[Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah"); [Ronald Lacey](/wiki/Ronald_Lacey "Ronald
Lacey") as [Gestapo](/wiki/Gestapo "Gestapo") agent [Arnold
Toht](/wiki/Arnold_Toht "Arnold Toht"); and [Denholm
Elliott](/wiki/Denholm_Elliott "Denholm Elliott") as Indiana's colleague,
[Marcus Brody](/wiki/Marcus_Brody "Marcus Brody").

The film originated from Lucas' desire to create a modern version of the
[serials](/wiki/Serial_film "Serial film") of the 1930s and 1940s. Production
was based at [Elstree Studios](/wiki/Elstree_Studios "Elstree Studios"),
England; but filming also took place in [La Rochelle,
France](/wiki/La_Rochelle,_France "La Rochelle, France"),
[Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia "Tunisia"), [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), and
[California](/wiki/California "California") from June to September 1980.

Released on June 12, 1981, _Raiders of the Lost Ark_ became the year's
top-[grossing](/wiki/Gross_income "Gross income") film and remains one of the
[highest-grossing films](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of
highest-grossing films") ever made. It was nominated for eight [Academy
Awards](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") in
[1982](/wiki/54th_Academy_Awards "54th Academy Awards"), including [Best
Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture"), and won four for [Best Art
Direction](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Production_Design "Academy Award for
Best Production Design"), [Film
Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Film_Editing "Academy Award for Best
Film Editing"), [Sound](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound "Academy Award for
Best Sound"), and [Visual Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects
"Academy Award for Best Visual Effects") with a fifth Academy Award: a Special
Achievement Award for [Sound Effects
Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound_Editing "Academy Award for Best
Sound Editing"). The film's critical and popular success led to three
additional films, _[Indiana Jones and the Temple of
Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple
of Doom")_ (1984), _[Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade "Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade")_ (1989), and _[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal
Skull](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull")_ (2008), with a [fifth slated for
2020](/wiki/Indy_5 "Indy 5"); the television series _[The Young Indiana Jones
Chronicles](/wiki/The_Young_Indiana_Jones_Chronicles "The Young Indiana Jones
Chronicles")_ (1992–1996), and 15 [video
games](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_franchise#Video_games "Indiana Jones franchise") as
of 2009. In 1999, the film was included in the U.S. [Library of
Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress")' [National Film
Registry](/wiki/National_Film_Registry "National Film Registry") as having
been deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".

_Raiders of the Lost Ark_ is often ranked as one of the [greatest films of all
time](/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best "List of films considered the
best"), both in the action-adventure genre, and in general.[3] The film also
ranks #2 on _[Empire](/wiki/Empire_magazine "Empire magazine")'_s 2008 list of
the 500 greatest movies of all time.[4]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

In 1936, archaeologist [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones")
braves an ancient booby-trapped temple in [Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru") and
retrieves a [golden idol](/wiki/Golden_Idol "Golden Idol"). He is confronted
by rival archaeologist [René
Belloq](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Ren.C3.A9_Belloq
"List of characters in the Indiana Jones series") and the indigenous
[Hovito](/wiki/Jibito_people "Jibito people") people. Surrounded and
outnumbered, Indy surrenders the idol to Belloq and escapes aboard a waiting
[floatplane](/wiki/Floatplane "Floatplane").

Jones returns to his teaching position at a New England college, where he is
interviewed by two [Army
Intelligence](/wiki/Military_Intelligence_Corps_\(United_States_Army\)
"Military Intelligence Corps \(United States Army\)") agents. They inform him
that the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") are searching for his old
mentor, Abner Ravenwood, under whom Jones studied at the [University of
Chicago](/wiki/University_of_Chicago "University of Chicago"). The Nazis know
that Ravenwood is the leading expert on the ancient city of
[Tanis](/wiki/Tanis "Tanis") in [Egypt](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt "Kingdom of
Egypt"), and that he possesses the headpiece of the Staff of [Ra](/wiki/Ra
"Ra"). Jones deduces that the Nazis are searching for the [Ark of the
Covenant](/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant "Ark of the Covenant") – the Nazis believe
that if they acquire the Ark, their armies will become invincible. The Staff
of Ra is the key to finding the [Well of Souls](/wiki/Well_of_Souls "Well of
Souls"), a secret chamber in which the Ark is buried.

The agents authorize Jones to recover the Ark to prevent the Nazis from
obtaining it. He travels to [Nepal](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Nepal "Kingdom of Nepal")
and discovers that Abner has died, and the headpiece is in the possession of
Ravenwood's daughter [Marion](/wiki/Marion_Ravenwood "Marion Ravenwood").
Jones visits Marion at her [tavern](/wiki/Tavern "Tavern"), where she reveals
her bitter feelings toward him from a previous romantic affair. She physically
rebuffs his offer to buy the headpiece, and Jones leaves. Shortly after, a
group of thugs arrive with their Nazi commander, [Arnold
Toht](/wiki/List_of_Indiana_Jones_characters#Arnold_Ernst_Toht "List of
Indiana Jones characters"). Toht threatens Marion to get the headpiece, but
when Jones returns to the bar to fight the Nazis and save Marion, her bar is
accidentally set on fire; during the fight, the headpiece ends up in the fire
and Toht severely burns his hand trying to take the hot headpiece, and flees
the tavern screaming. Indy and Marion escape with the headpiece, and Marion
decides to accompany Indy in his search for the Ark so he can repay his debt
to her.

The pair travels to [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"), where they meet up with
Indy's friend [Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah"), a skilled
[excavator](/wiki/Excavation_\(archaeology\) "Excavation \(archaeology\)").
Sallah informs them that Belloq and the Nazis are digging for the Well of
Souls with a replica of the headpiece (created from the scar on Toht's hand).
They quickly realize the Nazi headpiece is incomplete and that the Nazis are
digging in the wrong place. The Nazis kidnap Marion and it appears to Jones
that she is killed in an exploding truck. After a confrontation with Belloq in
a local bar, Indy and Sallah infiltrate the Nazi dig site and use their staff
to correctly locate the Ark. Indy discovers Marion is alive, bound and gagged
in a tent, but does not release her for fear of alerting the Nazis. Indy,
Sallah, and a small group of diggers unearth the Well of Souls and acquire the
Ark. Belloq and Nazi officer [Colonel
Dietrich](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Colonel_Dietrich
"List of characters in the Indiana Jones series") arrive, seize the Ark from
Jones, throwing Marion into the Well of Souls with him before sealing it back
up. Jones and Marion escape to a local airstrip, where Jones has a fistfight
with a Nazi mechanic and destroys the [flying wing](/wiki/Flying_wing "Flying
wing") that was to transport the Ark to [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"). The
panicked Nazis remove the Ark in a truck and set off for Cairo, but Jones
catches them and retakes it. He makes arrangements to take the Ark to
[London](/wiki/London "London") aboard a [tramp steamer](/wiki/Tramp_trade
"Tramp trade").

The next day, a Nazi [U-boat](/wiki/U-boat "U-boat") appears and intercepts
the ship. Belloq and Dietrich seize the Ark and Marion but cannot locate
Jones, who stows away aboard the U-boat and travels with them to an island in
the [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea"). Once there, Belloq plans to
test the power of the Ark before presenting it to [Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler
"Adolf Hitler"). Jones reveals himself and threatens to destroy the Ark with a
[panzerfaust](/wiki/Panzerfaust "Panzerfaust"), but Belloq calls his bluff and
Jones surrenders rather than destroy such an important historical artifact.
The Nazis take Indy and Marion to an area where the Ark will be opened and tie
them to a post to observe. Belloq performs a ceremonial opening of the Ark,
which appears to contain nothing but sand, all that remains of the Ten
Commandments. Suddenly, angelic ghost-like beings emerge from the Ark. Indy
cautions Marion to keep her eyes closed and not to observe what happens next.
Belloq and the others look on in astonishment as the apparitions are suddenly
revealed to be angels of death. A [vortex of
flame](/wiki/Pillar_of_Fire_\(theophany\) "Pillar of Fire \(theophany\)")
forms above the Ark and shoots bolts of fiery energy into the gathered Nazi
soldiers, killing them all. As Belloq, Toht and Dietrich all scream in terror,
the Ark turns its fury on them: Dietrich's head shrivels up, Toht's face is
melted off his skull and Belloq's head explodes. Flames then engulf the
remains of the doomed assembly, save for Indy and Marion, and the pillar of
fire rises into the sky. The Ark's lid is blasted high into the air before
dropping back down onto the Ark and sealing it. Jones and Marion find their
ropes burned off and embrace.

In [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), the Army
Intelligence agents inform Jones and [Marcus Brody](/wiki/Marcus_Brody "Marcus
Brody") that the Ark is someplace safe and will be studied by "top men". The
Ark is shown being stored in a giant government warehouse among countless
similar crates.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

See also: [List of Indiana Jones
characters](/wiki/List_of_Indiana_Jones_characters "List of Indiana Jones
characters")

  * [Harrison Ford](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison Ford") stars as [Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones "Indiana Jones"), an [archaeology](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") professor who often embarks on perilous adventures to obtain rare artifacts. Jones claims that he has no belief in the supernatural, only to have his skepticism challenged when he discovers the Ark. Spielberg suggested casting Ford as Jones, but Lucas objected, stating that he did not want Ford to become his "[Bobby De Niro](/wiki/Robert_De_Niro "Robert De Niro")" or "that guy I put in all my movies"—a reference to [Martin Scorsese](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese "Martin Scorsese"), who [often worked with](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese_and_Robert_De_Niro "Martin Scorsese and Robert De Niro") Robert De Niro.[5] Desiring a lesser known actor, Lucas persuaded Spielberg to help him search for a new talent. Among the actors who auditioned were [Tim Matheson](/wiki/Tim_Matheson "Tim Matheson"), [Peter Coyote](/wiki/Peter_Coyote "Peter Coyote"), [John Shea](/wiki/John_Shea "John Shea"), and [Tom Selleck](/wiki/Tom_Selleck "Tom Selleck"). Selleck was originally offered the role, but became unavailable for the part because of his commitment to the television series _[Magnum, P.I.](/wiki/Magnum,_P.I. "Magnum, P.I.")_.[5][6][6] In June 1980, three weeks away from filming,[7] Spielberg persuaded Lucas to cast Ford after producers [Frank Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(film_producer\) "Frank Marshall \(film producer\)") and [Kathleen Kennedy](/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy_\(film_producer\) "Kathleen Kennedy \(film producer\)") were impressed by his performance as [Han Solo](/wiki/Han_Solo "Han Solo") in _[The Empire Strikes Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire Strikes Back")_.[8]
  * [Paul Freeman](/wiki/Paul_Freeman_\(actor\) "Paul Freeman \(actor\)") as Dr. [René Belloq](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Ren.C3.A9_Belloq "List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"), Jones' rival. Belloq is also an archaeologist after the Ark, but he is working for the Nazis. He intends to harness the Ark's power himself before [Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") can, but he is killed by the Ark's supernatural powers. Spielberg cast Freeman after seeing him in _[Death of a Princess](/wiki/Death_of_a_Princess "Death of a Princess")_.[9] Before Freeman got the part, actor [Giancarlo Giannini](/wiki/Giancarlo_Giannini "Giancarlo Giannini") was originally going to portray Belloq,[10] while singer [Jacques Dutronc](/wiki/Jacques_Dutronc "Jacques Dutronc") auditioned for the role, but they lost out to Freeman.
  * [Karen Allen](/wiki/Karen_Allen "Karen Allen") as [Marion Ravenwood](/wiki/Marion_Ravenwood "Marion Ravenwood"), a spirited, tough former lover of Indiana's. She is the daughter of Abner Ravenwood, Indiana Jones' mentor, and owns a bar in Nepal. Allen was cast after auditioning with Matheson and [John Shea](/wiki/John_Shea "John Shea"). Spielberg was interested in her, as he had seen her performance in _[National Lampoon's Animal House](/wiki/National_Lampoon%27s_Animal_House "National Lampoon's Animal House")_. [Sean Young](/wiki/Sean_Young "Sean Young") had previously auditioned for the part,[5] while [Debra Winger](/wiki/Debra_Winger "Debra Winger") turned it down.[11]
  * [John Rhys-Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies "John Rhys-Davies") as [Sallah](/wiki/Sallah "Sallah"), "the best digger in Egypt" according to Indiana, who has been hired by the Nazis to help them excavate Tanis. He is an old friend of Indiana's, and agrees to help him obtain the Ark, though he fears disturbing it. Spielberg initially approached [Danny DeVito](/wiki/Danny_DeVito "Danny DeVito") to play Sallah, but he could not play the part due to scheduling conflicts. Spielberg cast Rhys-Davies after seeing his performance in _[Shōgun](/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dgun_\(miniseries\) "Shōgun \(miniseries\)")_.[5]
  * [Ronald Lacey](/wiki/Ronald_Lacey "Ronald Lacey") as Major [Arnold Toht](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Toht "List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"), an interrogator for the [Gestapo](/wiki/Gestapo "Gestapo") and Jones' nemesis, who tries to torture Marion Ravenwood for the headpiece of the Staff of Ra. He is killed by the Ark's supernatural powers. Lacey was cast as he reminded Spielberg of [Peter Lorre](/wiki/Peter_Lorre "Peter Lorre").[5] Spielberg had originally offered the role to [Roman Polanski](/wiki/Roman_Polanski "Roman Polanski"), who was intrigued at the opportunity to work with Spielberg but decided to turn down the role because he wouldn't be able to make the trip to [Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia "Tunisia").[12] [Klaus Kinski](/wiki/Klaus_Kinski "Klaus Kinski") was also offered the role, but he hated the script,[13] calling it "moronically shitty".[14] [Michael Sheard](/wiki/Michael_Sheard "Michael Sheard"), who ended portraying Captain Oskar Schomburg in the film, also auditioned for the role, but he lost out to Lacey.[15]
  * [Denholm Elliott](/wiki/Denholm_Elliott "Denholm Elliott") as Dr. [Marcus Brody](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Marcus_Brody "List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"), a [museum curator](/wiki/Museum_curator "Museum curator"), who buys the artifacts Indiana obtains for display in his museum. The U.S. government agents approach him with regard to the Ark's recovery, and he sets up a meeting between them and Indiana Jones. Spielberg hired Elliott as he was a big fan of the actor, who had performed in some of his favorite British and American films.[5]
  * [Wolf Kahler](/wiki/Wolf_Kahler "Wolf Kahler") as [Colonel Dietrich](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Colonel_Dietrich "List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"), a ruthless German officer leading the operation to secure the Ark. He is killed by the Ark's supernatural powers.
  * [Alfred Molina](/wiki/Alfred_Molina "Alfred Molina"), in his film debut, as [Satipo](/wiki/List_of_characters_in_the_Indiana_Jones_series#Satipo "List of characters in the Indiana Jones series"), one of Jones' guides through the South American jungle. He betrays Jones and steals the golden idol, but is killed by traps before he can leave the temple.
  * [George Harris](/wiki/George_Harris_\(actor\) "George Harris \(actor\)") as Simon Katanga, captain of the _Bantu Wind_.
  * [Anthony Higgins](/wiki/Anthony_Higgins_\(actor\) "Anthony Higgins \(actor\)") as Major Gobler, Colonel Dietrich's right-hand-man.
  * [Vic Tablian](/wiki/Vic_Tablian "Vic Tablian") as Barranca and the Monkey Man.
  * [Don Fellows](/wiki/Don_Fellows "Don Fellows") as Colonel Musgrove, an Army Intelligence agent.
  * [William Hootkins](/wiki/William_Hootkins "William Hootkins") as Major Eaton, an Army Intelligence agent.

Producer [Frank Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(film_producer\) "Frank
Marshall \(film producer\)") played a pilot in the airplane fight sequence.
The stunt team was ill, so he took the role instead. The result was three days
in a hot cockpit, which he joked was over "140 degrees".[5] [Pat
Roach](/wiki/Pat_Roach "Pat Roach") plays the Nazi mechanic with whom Jones
brawls in this sequence, as well as a massive sherpa who battles Jones in
Marion's bar. He had the rare opportunity to be killed twice in one film.[16]
Special-effects supervisor [Dennis Muren](/wiki/Dennis_Muren "Dennis Muren")
made a [cameo](/wiki/Cameo_appearance "Cameo appearance") as a Nazi spy on the
[seaplane](/wiki/Seaplane "Seaplane") Jones takes from [San
Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") to [Manila](/wiki/Manila
"Manila").[17]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

In 1973, [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas") wrote _The
Adventures of Indiana Smith_.[18] Like _[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\)
"Star Wars \(film\)"),_ which he also wrote, it was an opportunity to create a
modern version of the [film serials](/wiki/Movie_serial "Movie serial") of the
1930s and 1940s.[5] Lucas discussed the concept with [Philip
Kaufman](/wiki/Philip_Kaufman "Philip Kaufman"), who worked with him for
several weeks and came up with the [Ark of the
Covenant](/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant "Ark of the Covenant") as the [plot
device](/wiki/Plot_device "Plot device").[19] Kaufman was told about the Ark
by his dentist when he was a child.[20] The project stalled when [Clint
Eastwood](/wiki/Clint_Eastwood "Clint Eastwood") hired Kaufman to direct _[The
Outlaw Josey Wales](/wiki/The_Outlaw_Josey_Wales "The Outlaw Josey
Wales")_.[19] Lucas shelved the idea, deciding to concentrate on his outer
space adventure that would become _Star Wars_. In late May 1977, Lucas was in
[Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii_\(island\) "Hawaii \(island\)"), trying to escape the
enormous success of _Star Wars_. Friend and colleague [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg") was also there, on
vacation from work on _[Close Encounters of the Third
Kind](/wiki/Close_Encounters_of_the_Third_Kind "Close Encounters of the Third
Kind")_. While building a sand castle at the [Mauna Kea Beach
Hotel](/wiki/Mauna_Kea_Beach_Hotel "Mauna Kea Beach Hotel"),[21] Spielberg
expressed an interest in directing a [James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James
Bond") film. Lucas convinced his friend Spielberg that he had conceived a
character "better than James Bond" and explained the concept of _Raiders of
the Lost Ark_. Spielberg loved it, calling it "a James Bond film without the
hardware",[22] although he told Lucas that the surname 'Smith' was not right
for the character. Lucas replied, "OK. What about 'Jones'?" Indiana was the
name of Lucas' [Alaskan Malamute](/wiki/Alaskan_Malamute "Alaskan Malamute"),
whose habit of riding in the passenger seat as Lucas drove was also the
inspiration for Star Wars' [Chewbacca](/wiki/Chewbacca "Chewbacca").[5]
Spielberg was at first reluctant to sign on, as Lucas had told him that he
would want Spielberg for an entire trilogy, and Spielberg did not want to work
on two more scripts. Lucas told him, however, that he already had the next two
movies written, so Spielberg agreed. But when the time came for the first
sequel, it was revealed that Lucas had nothing written for either sequel.[5]

The following year, Lucas focused on developing _Raiders_ and the _Star Wars_
sequel _[The Empire Strikes Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire
Strikes Back")_ , during which [Lawrence Kasdan](/wiki/Lawrence_Kasdan
"Lawrence Kasdan") and [Frank Marshall](/wiki/Frank_Marshall_\(film_producer\)
"Frank Marshall \(film producer\)") joined the project as screenwriter and
producer respectively. Between January 23 – 27, 1978, for nine hours a day,
Lucas, Kasdan, and Spielberg discussed the story and visual ideas. Spielberg
came up with Jones being chased by a boulder,[5] which was inspired by [Carl
Barks](/wiki/Carl_Barks "Carl Barks")' [Uncle Scrooge](/wiki/Uncle_Scrooge
"Uncle Scrooge") comic "The Seven Cities of Cibola". Lucas later acknowledged
that the idea for the idol mechanism in the opening scene and deadly traps
later in the film were inspired by several Uncle Scrooge comics.[23] Lucas
came up with a submarine, a monkey giving the [Hitler
salute](/wiki/Hitler_salute "Hitler salute"), and Marion punching Jones in
[Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal").[22] Kasdan used a 100-page transcript of their
conversations for his first script draft,[24] which he worked on for six
months.[5] Ultimately, some of their ideas were too grand and had to be cut: a
mine chase,[25] an escape in [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai") using a
rolling gong as a shield,[26] and a jump from an airplane in a raft, all of
which made it into the prequel, _[Indiana Jones and the Temple of
Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple
of Doom")_.[5]

Spielberg and Lucas disagreed on the character: although Spielberg saw him as
a Bondian playboy, Lucas felt the character's academic and adventurer elements
made him complex enough.[27] Spielberg had a darker vision of Jones,
interpreting him as an [alcoholic](/wiki/Alcoholic "Alcoholic") similar to
[Humphrey Bogart](/wiki/Humphrey_Bogart "Humphrey Bogart")'s character Fred C.
Dobbs in _[The Treasure of the Sierra
Madre](/wiki/The_Treasure_of_the_Sierra_Madre_\(film\) "The Treasure of the
Sierra Madre \(film\)")_ (1948). This characterization fell away during the
later drafts, though elements survive in Jones's reaction when he believes
Marion to be dead.[22] Costume designer [Deborah
Nadoolman](/wiki/Deborah_Nadoolman "Deborah Nadoolman") credits _[Secret of
the Incas](/wiki/Secret_of_the_Incas "Secret of the Incas")_ (1954), starring
[Charlton Heston](/wiki/Charlton_Heston "Charlton Heston"), as an influence on
the development of the character, noting that the crew watched the film
together several times. Nadoolman based the look of Ford's costume on that of
Heston's, and observed that Indiana is a "kinder and gentler" Harry
Steele.[28]

Initially, the film was rejected by every major studio in
[Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood"), mostly due to the $20 million budget
and the deal Lucas was offering.[29] Eventually Paramount agreed to finance
the film, with Lucas negotiating a five-picture deal. By April 1980, Kasdan's
fifth draft was produced, and production was getting ready to shoot at
[Elstree Studios](/wiki/Elstree_Studios "Elstree Studios"), with Lucas trying
to keep costs down.[8] With four illustrators, _Raiders of the Lost Ark_ was
Spielberg's most [storyboarded](/wiki/Storyboard "Storyboard") film of his
career to date, further helping the film economically. He and Lucas agreed on
a tight schedule to keep costs down and to follow the "quick and dirty" feel
of the old Saturday matinée serials. Special effects were done using puppets,
miniature models, animation, and camera trickery.[5] "We didn't do 30 or 40
takes; usually only four. It was like silent film--shoot only what you need,
no waste", Spielberg said. "Had I had more time and money, it would have
turned out a pretentious movie."[30]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Filming")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began on June 23, 1980, at [La Rochelle](/wiki/La_Rochelle "La Rochelle"),
France, with scenes involving the Nazi submarine,[8] which had been rented
from the production of _[Das Boot](/wiki/Das_Boot "Das Boot")_. The U-boat pen
was a real one from [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[5] The
crew moved to [Elstree Studios](/wiki/Elstree_Studios "Elstree Studios")[8]
for the [Well of Souls](/wiki/Well_of_Souls "Well of Souls") scenes, the
opening sequence temple interiors and [Marion
Ravenwood](/wiki/Marion_Ravenwood "Marion Ravenwood")'s bar.[31] The Well of
Souls scene required 7,000 snakes. The only venomous snakes were the
[cobras](/wiki/Cobras "Cobras"), but one crew member was bitten on set by a
python.[5] The bulk of the snakes' numbers were made up with giant but
harmless legless lizards known as [Scheltopusiks](/wiki/Scheltopusik
"Scheltopusik") (_Pseudopus apodus_) which occur from the [Balkan
Peninsula](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") of southeastern Europe to [Central
Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"). Growing to 1.3 m they are the
largest [legless lizards](/wiki/Legless_lizard "Legless lizard") in the world
and are often mistaken for snakes despite some very obvious differences such
as the presence of eyelids and external ear openings, which are both absent
from all snakes, and a notched rather than forked tongue. In the finished
film, during the scene in which Indiana comes face-to-face with the cobra, a
reflection in glass screen that protected Ford from the snake was seen,[5] an
issue that was corrected in the 2003 digitally-enhanced re-release. Unlike
Indiana, neither Ford nor Spielberg has a fear of snakes, but Spielberg said
that seeing all the snakes on the set writhing around made him "want to
puke".[5]

The opening scene in the Peruvian jungle was filmed on the island of
[Kauai](/wiki/Kauai "Kauai"), one of the islands of Hawaii, to where Spielberg
would return for _[Jurassic Park](/wiki/Jurassic_Park "Jurassic Park")_. The
"temple" location is on the Huleia River, on the Kipu Ranch, south from
Kaumualii Highway on the east coast, just south of [Lihue](/wiki/Lihue
"Lihue"), the island's main town. Kipu is a working cattle ranch, not
generally open to the public.[32] The Peruvian section (but actually filmed in
Hawaii) featured live [tarantulas](/wiki/Tarantulas "Tarantulas") of a Mexican
species (_[Brachypelma](/wiki/Brachypelma "Brachypelma")_) on [Harrison
Ford](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison Ford") and [Alfred
Molina](/wiki/Alfred_Molina "Alfred Molina"), and are harmless to humans, and
in fact of a species which are commonly kept as exotic pets. A
[fiberglass](/wiki/Fiberglass "Fiberglass") boulder 22 feet (7 m) in diameter
was made for the scene where Indiana escapes from the temple; Spielberg was so
impressed by production designer Norman Reynolds' realization of his idea that
he gave the boulder a more prominent role in the film and told Reynolds to let
the boulder roll another 50 feet (15 m).[33]

The scenes set in [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") were filmed in
[Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia "Tunisia"), and the canyon where Indiana threatens to
blow up the Ark was shot in Sidi Bouhlel, just outside [Tozeur](/wiki/Tozeur
"Tozeur").[34] The canyon location had been used for the
[Tatooine](/wiki/Tatooine "Tatooine") scenes from 1977's _[Star
Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\) "Star Wars \(film\)")_ (many of the location
crew members were the same for both films[5]) where [R2-D2](/wiki/R2-D2
"R2-D2") was attacked by [Jawas](/wiki/List_of_Star_Wars_races_\(F-J\)#Jawa
"List of Star Wars races \(F-J\)").[5] The Tanis scenes were filmed in nearby
Sedala, a harsh place due to heat and disease. Several cast and crew members
fell ill and Rhys-Davies [defecated](/wiki/Defecation "Defecation") in his
costume during one shot.[5] Spielberg averted disease by eating only [canned
foods](/wiki/Canned_food "Canned food") from England, but did not like the
area and quickly condensed the scheduled six-week shoot to four-and-a-half
weeks. Much was improvised: the scene where Marion puts on her dress and
attempts to leave Belloq's tent was improvised as was the entire plane fight.
During that scene's shooting, a wheel went over Ford's knee and tore his left
leg's [cruciate ligament](/wiki/Cruciate_ligament "Cruciate ligament"), but he
refused local medical help and simply put ice on it.[5]

The fight scenes in the town were filmed in [Kairouan](/wiki/Kairouan
"Kairouan"), while Ford was suffering from [dysentery](/wiki/Dysentery
"Dysentery"). Stuntman [Terry Richards](/wiki/Terry_Richards_\(actor\) "Terry
Richards \(actor\)") had practiced for weeks with his sword to create the
scripted fight scene, choreographing a fight between the swordsman and Jones'
whip.[35] However, after filming the initial shots of the scene, after lunch
due to Ford's dysentery, Ford and Spielberg agreed to cut the scene down to a
gunshot, with Ford saying to Spielberg "Let's just shoot the sucker".[36] It
was later voted in at No.5 on [_Playboy_](/wiki/Playboy_magazine "Playboy
magazine") magazine's list of best all time scenes.[35][37] Most of the truck
chase was shot by [second unit](/wiki/Second_unit "Second unit") director
[Michael D. Moore](/wiki/Michael_D._Moore "Michael D. Moore") following
Spielberg's storyboards, including Indiana being dragged by the truck
(performed by stuntman Terry Leonard), in tribute to a famous [Yakima
Canutt](/wiki/Yakima_Canutt "Yakima Canutt") stunt. Spielberg then filmed all
the shots with Ford himself in and around the truck cab.[5] Lucas directed a
few other second unit shots, in particular the monkey giving the Nazi
salute.[30]

The interior staircase set in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C.") was filmed in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San
Francisco")'s [City Hall](/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall "San Francisco City
Hall"). The [University of the
Pacific](/wiki/University_of_the_Pacific_\(United_States\) "University of the
Pacific \(United States\)")'s campus in [Stockton,
California](/wiki/Stockton,_California "Stockton, California"), stood in for
the exterior of the college where Jones works, while his classroom and the
hall where he meets the American intelligence agents was filmed at the [Royal
Masonic School for Girls](/wiki/Royal_Masonic_School_for_Girls "Royal Masonic
School for Girls") in [Rickmansworth](/wiki/Rickmansworth "Rickmansworth"),
[Hertfordshire](/wiki/Hertfordshire "Hertfordshire"), [England](/wiki/England
"England"), which was again used in _[The Last
Crusade](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade "Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade")_. His home exteriors were filmed in [San Rafael,
California](/wiki/San_Rafael,_California "San Rafael, California").[31]
Opening sequence exteriors were filmed in [Kauai](/wiki/Kauai "Kauai"),
Hawaii, with Spielberg wrapping in September in 73 days, finishing under
schedule in contrast to his previous film, _[1941](/wiki/1941_\(film\) "1941
\(film\)")_.[8][22] The Washington, D.C. coda, although it appeared in the
script's early drafts, was not included in early edits but was added later
when it was realized that there was no resolution to Jones' relationship with
Marion.[38] Shots of the [Douglas DC-3](/wiki/Douglas_DC-3 "Douglas DC-3")
Jones flies on to Nepal were taken from _[Lost
Horizon](/wiki/Lost_Horizon_\(1973_film\) "Lost Horizon \(1973 film\)")_ , and
a street scene was from a shot in _[The
Hindenburg](/wiki/The_Hindenburg_\(film\) "The Hindenburg \(film\)")_.[30]
Filming of Jones boarding a Boeing [Clipper](/wiki/Boeing_314 "Boeing 314")
flying-boat was complicated by the lack of a surviving aircraft. Eventually, a
post-war British [Short Solent](/wiki/Short_Solent "Short Solent") flying-boat
formerly owned by [Howard Hughes](/wiki/Howard_Hughes "Howard Hughes") was
located in California and substituted.[39]

### Visual effects and sound
design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Visual effects and sound design")]

The special visual effects for _Raiders_ were provided by [Industrial Light &
Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light & Magic") and
include: a matte shot to establish the Pan Am [flying boat](/wiki/Flying_boat
"Flying boat") in the water[40] and miniature work to show the plane taking
off and flying, superimposed over a map; animation effects for the beam in the
Tanis map room; and a miniature car and passengers[41] superimposed over a
matte painting for a shot of a Nazi car being forced off a cliff. The bulk of
effects shots were featured in the climactic sequence wherein the Ark of the
Covenant (which was designed by [Brian Muir](/wiki/Brian_Muir_\(sculptor\)
"Brian Muir \(sculptor\)") and [Keith Short](/wiki/Keith_Short "Keith Short"))
is opened and God's wrath is unleashed. This sequence featured animation, a
woman to portray a beautiful spirit's face, rod puppet spirits moved through
water to convey a sense of floating,[42] a matte painting of the island, and
cloud tank effects to portray clouds. The melting of Toht's head was done by
exposing a gelatine and plaster model of Ronald Lacey's head to a heat lamp
with an under-cranked camera, while Dietrich's crushed head was a hollow model
from which air was withdrawn. When the film was originally submitted to the
[Motion Picture Association of
America](/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_of_America "Motion Picture
Association of America"), it received an R rating because of the scene in
which Belloq's head explodes. The filmmakers were able to receive a PG rating
when they added a veil of fire over the exploding head scene.
([PG-13](/wiki/PG-13 "PG-13") rating was not created until 1984.[17]) The
firestorm that cleanses the canyon at the finish was a miniature canyon filmed
upside down.[42]

[Ben Burtt](/wiki/Ben_Burtt "Ben Burtt"), the sound effects supervisor, made
extensive use of traditional [foley](/wiki/Foley_\(filmmaking\) "Foley
\(filmmaking\)") work in yet another of the production's throwbacks to days of
the [Republic](/wiki/Republic_Pictures "Republic Pictures")
[serials](/wiki/Serial_film "Serial film"). He selected a [.30-30
Winchester](/wiki/.30-30_Winchester ".30-30 Winchester") rifle for the sound
of Jones' [pistol](/wiki/Pistol "Pistol"). Sound effects artists struck
leather jackets and [baseball gloves](/wiki/Baseball_glove "Baseball glove")
with a [baseball bat](/wiki/Baseball_bat "Baseball bat") to create a variety
of punching noises and body blows. For the snakes in the Well of Souls
sequence, fingers running through cheese casserole and sponges sliding over
concrete were used for the slithering noises. The sliding lid on a toilet
cistern provided the sound for the opening of the Ark, and the sound of the
boulder in the opening is a car rolling down a gravel driveway in neutral.
Burtt also used, as he did in many of his films, the ubiquitous [Wilhelm
scream](/wiki/Wilhelm_scream "Wilhelm scream") when a Nazi falls from a truck.
In addition to his use of such time-honored foley work, Burtt also
demonstrated the modern expertise honed during his award-winning work on _Star
Wars_. He employed a synthesizer for the sounds of the Ark, and mixed
dolphins' and sea lions' screams for those of the spirits within.[43]

###

"Edit section: Music")]

Main article: [Raiders of the Lost Ark
(soundtrack)](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark_\(soundtrack\) "Raiders of the
Lost Ark \(soundtrack\)")

[John Williams](/wiki/John_Williams "John Williams") composed the score for
_Raiders of the Lost Ark_ , which was the only score in the series performed
by the [London Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra "London
Symphony Orchestra"), the same orchestra that performed the scores for the
_[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ saga. The score most notably
features the well-known "Raiders March". This piece came to symbolize Indiana
Jones and was later used in the scores for the other three films. Williams
originally wrote two different candidates for Jones's theme, but Spielberg
enjoyed them so much that he insisted that both be used together in what
became the "Raiders March".[44] The alternately eerie and apocalyptic theme
for the Ark of the Covenant is also heard frequently in the score, with a more
romantic melody representing Marion and, more broadly, her relationship with
Jones. The score as a whole received an Oscar nomination for Best Original
Score, but lost to the score to _[Chariots of Fire](/wiki/Chariots_of_Fire
"Chariots of Fire")_ composed by [Vangelis](/wiki/Vangelis "Vangelis").

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Release")]

###
Merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Merchandise")]

The only [video game](/wiki/Video_game "Video game") based exclusively on the
film is _[Raiders of the Lost
Ark](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark_\(Atari_2600\) "Raiders of the Lost Ark
\(Atari 2600\)")_ , released in 1982 by [Atari](/wiki/Atari "Atari") for their
[Atari 2600](/wiki/Atari_2600 "Atari 2600") console.[45] The first third of
the video game _[Indiana Jones' Greatest
Adventures](/wiki/Indiana_Jones%27_Greatest_Adventures "Indiana Jones'
Greatest Adventures")_, released in 1994 by JVC for [Nintendo](/wiki/Nintendo
"Nintendo")'s [Super Nintendo Entertainment
System](/wiki/Super_Nintendo_Entertainment_System "Super Nintendo
Entertainment System"), is based entirely on the film. Several of the film's
sequences are reproduced (the boulder run and the showdown with the Cairo
Swordsman among them); however, several inconsistencies with the film are
present in the game, such as Nazi soldiers and bats being present in the Well
of Souls sequence, for example.[46] The game was developed by
[LucasArts](/wiki/LucasArts "LucasArts") and [Factor 5](/wiki/Factor_5 "Factor
5"). In the 1999 game _[Indiana Jones and the Infernal
Machine](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Infernal_Machine "Indiana Jones and the
Infernal Machine")_ , a bonus level brings Jones back to the Peruvian temple
of the film's opening scene.[47] In 2008, to coincide with the release of
_Kingdom of the Crystal Skull_ , [Lego](/wiki/Lego "Lego") released the _[Lego
Indiana Jones](/wiki/Lego_Indiana_Jones "Lego Indiana Jones")_ line—which
included building sets based on _Raiders of the Lost Ark_[48]—and LucasArts
published a video game based on the toyline, _[Lego Indiana Jones: The
Original Adventures](/wiki/Lego_Indiana_Jones:_The_Original_Adventures "Lego
Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures")_ , which was developed by
[Traveller's Tales](/wiki/Traveller%27s_Tales "Traveller's Tales").[49]

[Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics") published a comic book
adaptation of the film by writer [Walt Simonson](/wiki/Walt_Simonson "Walt
Simonson") and artists [John Buscema](/wiki/John_Buscema "John Buscema") and
[Klaus Janson](/wiki/Klaus_Janson "Klaus Janson"). It was published as
_[Marvel Super Special](/wiki/Marvel_Comics_Super_Special "Marvel Comics Super
Special")_ #18[50] and as a three-issue [limited series](/wiki/Limited_series
"Limited series").[51] This was followed with the comic book series _[The
Further Adventures of Indiana Jones](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_Comics "Indiana Jones
Comics")_ which was published monthly from January 1983 through March 1986.

In 1981, [Kenner](/wiki/Kenner_Products "Kenner Products") released a 12-inch
(30 cm) doll of Indiana Jones, and the following year they released nine
action figures of the film's characters, three [playsets](/wiki/Playset
"Playset"), as well as toys of the Nazi truck and Jones' horse. They also
released a [board game](/wiki/Board_game "Board game"). In 1984, miniature
metal versions of the characters were released for a [role playing
game](/wiki/Role_playing_game "Role playing game"), _[The Adventures of
Indiana Jones](/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Indiana_Jones_Role-Playing_Game "The
Adventures of Indiana Jones Role-Playing Game")_ , and in 1995 [Micro
Machines](/wiki/Micro_Machines "Micro Machines") released [die-cast
toys](/wiki/Die-cast_toy "Die-cast toy") of the film's vehicles.[52]
[Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro") released action figures based on the film,
ranging from 3 to 12 inches (7.6 to 30.5 cm), to coincide with _Kingdom of the
Crystal Skull_ on May 1, 2008.[53] Later in 2008, and in 2011, two high-end
sixth scale (1:6) collectible action figures were released by [Sideshow
Collectibles](/wiki/Sideshow_Collectibles "Sideshow Collectibles"), and [Hot
Toys, Ltd.](/wiki/Hot_Toys "Hot Toys") respectively. A
[novelization](/wiki/Novelization "Novelization") by Ryder Windham was
released in April 2008 by [Scholastic](/wiki/Scholastic_Corporation
"Scholastic Corporation") to tie in with the release of _Kingdom of the
Crystal Skull_. A previous [novelization](/wiki/Novelization "Novelization")
by Scottish author [Campbell Armstrong](/wiki/Campbell_Armstrong "Campbell
Armstrong") (under the pseudonym Campbell Black) was concurrently released
with the film in 1981. A book about the making of the film was also released,
written by [Derek Taylor](/wiki/Derek_Taylor "Derek Taylor").

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film was released on [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS"), [Betamax](/wiki/Betamax
"Betamax") and [VideoDisc](/wiki/Capacitance_Electronic_Disc "Capacitance
Electronic Disc") in [pan and scan](/wiki/Pan_and_scan "Pan and scan") only,
and on [laserdisc](/wiki/Laserdisc "Laserdisc") in both pan and scan and
[widescreen](/wiki/Widescreen "Widescreen"). For its 1999 VHS re-issue, the
film was remastered in [THX](/wiki/THX "THX") and made available in
widescreen. The outer package was retitled _Indiana Jones and the Raiders of
the Lost Ark_ for consistency with the film's
[prequel](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the
Temple of Doom") and [sequel](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade
"Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade"). The subsequent [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD")
release in 2003 features this title as well. The title in the film itself
remains unchanged, even in the restored DVD print. In the DVD, two subtle
digital revisions were added. First, a connecting rod from the giant boulder
to an offscreen guidance track in the opening scene was removed from behind
the running Harrison Ford; second, a reflection in the glass partition
separating Ford from the cobra in the Well of Souls was removed.[54] Shortly
before the theatrical release of _Kingdom of the Crystal Skull_ , _Raiders_
(along with _The Temple of Doom_ and _The Last Crusade_) was re-released on
DVD with additional extra features not included on the previous set on May 13,
2008. The film was released on [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray
Disc") in September 2012.[55] Previously, only _Kingdom of the Crystal Skull_
had been available on Blu-ray.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Box office")]

_Raiders of the Lost Ark_ opened at #14 and grossed $1,673,731 from 267
theaters ($6,269 theater average) during its opening weekend. In total, the
IMAX release grossed $3,125,613 domestically.[56] The film, made on an
[$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")18 million budget,
grossed $384 million worldwide throughout its theatrical releases. In North
America, it was by some distance the highest-grossing film of 1981,[57] and
remains one of the top twenty-five [highest-grossing
films](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_films "List of highest-grossing films")
ever made when adjusted for [inflation](/wiki/Inflation "Inflation").[58] [Box
Office Mojo](/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo "Box Office Mojo") estimates that the film
sold more than 70 million tickets in the US in its initial theatrical run.[59]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

The film was subsequently nominated for nine [Academy
Awards](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award"), including Best Picture, in 1982
and won four (Best Sound, Best Film Editing, Best Visual Effects, and Best Art
Direction-Set Decoration ([Norman Reynolds](/wiki/Norman_Reynolds "Norman
Reynolds"), [Leslie Dilley](/wiki/Leslie_Dilley "Leslie Dilley"), and [Michael
D. Ford](/wiki/Michael_D._Ford "Michael D. Ford")). It also received a Special
Achievement Award for Sound Effects Editing. It won numerous other awards,
including a [Grammy
Award](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media "Grammy
Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media") and Best Picture at the
[People's Choice Awards](/wiki/People%27s_Choice_Awards "People's Choice
Awards"). Spielberg was also nominated for a [Golden Globe
Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Director "Golden Globe Award for Best
Director").[60]

The film was highly acclaimed by critics and audiences alike. In his review
for _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ ,
[Vincent Canby](/wiki/Vincent_Canby "Vincent Canby") praised the film, calling
it, "one of the most deliriously funny, ingenious and stylish American
adventure movies ever made."[61] [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger
Ebert") in his review for the _[Chicago Sun-Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times
"Chicago Sun-Times")_ wrote, "Two things, however, make _Raiders of the Lost
Ark_ more than just a technological triumph: its sense of humor and the droll
style of its characters [...] We find ourselves laughing in surprise, in
relief, in incredulity at the movie's ability to pile one incident upon
another in an inexhaustible series of inventions."[62] He later added it to
his list of "Great Movies".[63] _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling
Stone")_ said the film was "the ultimate Saturday action matinee–a film so
funny and exciting it can be enjoyed any day of the week."[64] Bruce
Williamson of _[Playboy](/wiki/Playboy "Playboy")_ claimed: "There's more
excitement in the first ten minutes of _Raiders_ than any movie I have seen
all year. By the time the explosive misadventures end, any movie-goer worth
his salt ought to be exhausted."[65] Stephen Klain of
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ also praised
the film. Yet, making an observation that would revisit the franchise with its
next film, he felt that the film was surprisingly violent and bloody for a PG-
rated film.[66]

There were some dissenting voices: _[Sight& Sound](/wiki/Sight_%26_Sound
"Sight & Sound")_ described it as an "expensively gift-wrapped Saturday
afternoon pot-boiler",[67] and [New Hollywood](/wiki/New_Hollywood "New
Hollywood") champion [Pauline Kael](/wiki/Pauline_Kael "Pauline Kael"), who
once contended that she only got "really rough" on large films that were
destined to be hits but were nonetheless "atrocious",[68] found the film to be
a "machine-tooled adventure" from a pair of creators who "think just like the
marketing division".[69] (Lucas later named a villain, played by _Raiders_
Nazi strongman [Pat Roach](/wiki/Pat_Roach "Pat Roach"), in his 1988 fantasy
film _[Willow](/wiki/Willow_\(film\) "Willow \(film\)")_ after Kael.)[68] On
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film has a 94%
"Certified Fresh" rating on [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes"),[70] as well as a 85% rating on Metacritic, indicating "universal
acclaim".[71]

##
Impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Impact")]

Following the success of _Raiders_ , a prequel, _[The Temple of
Doom](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Temple_of_Doom "Indiana Jones and the Temple
of Doom")_ , and two sequels, _[The Last
Crusade](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Last_Crusade "Indiana Jones and the Last
Crusade")_ and _[Kingdom of the Crystal
Skull](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull")_ , were produced, with a third sequel
set for release in 2020.[75] A television series, entitled _[The Young Indiana
Jones Chronicles](/wiki/The_Young_Indiana_Jones_Chronicles "The Young Indiana
Jones Chronicles")_ , was also spun off from this film, and details the
character's early years. Numerous other books,
[comics](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_Comics "Indiana Jones Comics"), and video games
have also been produced.

In 1998, the [American Film Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American
Film Institute") placed the film at number 60 on its top 100 films of the
first century of cinema. In 2007, AFI updated the list and placed it at number
66. They also named it as the 10th most thrilling film, and named Indiana
Jones as the second greatest hero. In 1999, the film was deemed "culturally,
historically, or aesthetically significant" by the U.S. [Library of
Congress](/wiki/Library_of_Congress "Library of Congress") and selected for
preservation in the [National Film Registry](/wiki/National_Film_Registry
"National Film Registry"). Indiana Jones has become an icon, being listed as
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ 's
third favorite action hero, while noting "some of the greatest action scenes
ever filmed are strung together like pearls" in this film.[76]

An amateur, near shot-for-shot remake was made by Chris Strompolos, Eric Zala,
and Jayson Lamb, then children in [Ocean Springs,
Mississippi](/wiki/Ocean_Springs,_Mississippi "Ocean Springs, Mississippi").
It took the boys seven years to finish, from 1982 to 1989. After production of
the film, called _[Raiders of the Lost Ark: The
Adaptation](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark:_The_Adaptation "Raiders of the Lost
Ark: The Adaptation")_ , it was shelved and forgotten until 2003, where it was
discovered by [Eli Roth](/wiki/Eli_Roth "Eli Roth")[77][78] and acclaimed by
Spielberg himself, who congratulated the boys on their hard work and said he
looked forward to seeing their names on the big screen.[79] [Scott
Rudin](/wiki/Scott_Rudin "Scott Rudin") and [Paramount
Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures") purchased the trio's
life rights with the goal of producing a film based on their adventures making
their remake.[80][81]

In 2014, film director [Steven Soderbergh](/wiki/Steven_Soderbergh "Steven
Soderbergh") published an experimental black-and-white version of the film,
with the original soundtrack and dialogue replaced by an electronic
soundtrack. Soderbergh said his intention was to encourage viewers to focus on
Spielberg's extraordinary staging and editing: "This filmmaker forgot more
about staging by the time he made his first feature than I know to this
day."[82]

Assessing the film's legacy in 1997, Bernard Weinraub, film critic for _[The
New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , which had
initially reviewed the film as "deliriously funny, ingenious, and
stylish",[83] maintained that "the decline in the traditional family G-rated
film, for 'general' audiences, probably began" with the appearance of _Raiders
of the Lost Ark_. "Whether by accident or design," found Weinraub, "the
filmmakers made a comic nonstop action film intended mostly for adults but
also for children."[84] Eight years later, in 2005, viewers of [Channel
4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") rated the film as the 20th-best [family
film](/wiki/Family_film "Family film") of all time, with Spielberg taking best
over-all director honors.[85]

On _[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(magazine\) "Empire \(magazine\)")_ magazine's list
of the 500 Greatest Movies of All Time, _Raiders_ ranked second, beaten only
by _[The Godfather](/wiki/The_Godfather "The Godfather")_.[86]

In conjunction with the Blu-ray release, a limited one-week release in
[IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") theaters was announced for September 7, 2012. Steven
Spielberg and sound designer Ben Burtt supervised the format conversion. No
special effects or other visual elements were altered, but the audio was
enhanced for [surround sound](/wiki/Surround_sound "Surround sound").[87]

### 2012 replica
mystery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: 2012 replica mystery")]

In December 2012, the [University of Chicago](/wiki/University_of_Chicago
"University of Chicago")'s admissions department received a package in the
mail addressed to Henry Walton Jones, Jr., Indiana Jones' full name. The
address on the stamped package was listed for a hall that was the former home
of the university's geology and geography department. Inside the manila
envelope was a detailed [replica](/wiki/Replica "Replica") journal similar to
the one Jones used in the movie, as well as postcards and pictures of [Marion
Ravenwood](/wiki/Marion_Ravenwood "Marion Ravenwood"). The admissions
department posted pictures of the contents on its Internet blog, looking for
any information about the package. It was discovered that the package was part
of a set to be shipped from Guam to Italy that had been sold on
[eBay](/wiki/EBay "EBay"). The package with the journal had fallen out in
transit and a postal worker had sent it to the university, as it had a
complete address and postage, which turned out to be fake. All contents were
from a [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam") "prop replicator" who sells them all over the
world. The university will display its replica in the main lobby of the
Oriental Institute.[88]
